What did early Canadian pioneers eat?
A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name Laura Wilson Knox
Address Valco Ranch
Birthplace Ontario

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? April 1927
Where did you set up housekeeping? On farm where I now live
Where had you been living before that? In Toronto, Ont.
For how many people did you prepare meals? The last year for four people
How far was it to your nearest store? 2½ miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Every day
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Staple supplies as soap - salt - sugar - yeast - cake - R. Oats - other cereals - celery - pepper - vinegar

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Maple Leaf mostly
In what quantities did you buy it? 42 tons each
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? About $3.25
How much did you use Graham flour? Very little
Whole wheat flour? About 3 bags per year
Was flour milled locally? Yes, in the 30's
How far away? Not far away
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? About 25 cents
What other grain products did you use?

Cornmeal? Yes
Whole wheat? Yes
Farina? Yes
Other? Cream of Wheat, Polenta
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it?
1920, Knox, Mrs. Wilson

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? ... we had our own - fresh hogs in winter, canned beef and pork & beefing in summer ...
How did you get fresh meat? ... 2-3 weeks in summer and as long as it would keep during the winter ...
How often did you get fresh meat? ... we have been eating meat up to 20 yrs ...
How did you preserve meat? ... in Brine or dry salt up to 22 years ...
Has there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? ... yes ...
If so what year was it organized? ... 1921 ...
Did you use game? ... no ... What kinds? ...
For how long? ...
What part did fish play in the family diet? ... we wanted them ...
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? ... some times we had canned fish ...
Kinds? ... the usual ... fresh water fish such as pickerel - jackfish - mullet etc.

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? We still can fruit, meat, also chicken & vegetables.

To what extent? To a large extent, to save trips to locker in town.

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) **Well** - We have 3 wells - 1 in barn - 1 in yard - 1 in basement.

How far was this water from your home? **and one in basement**

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) **left water in barrels**

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Since 1927 we have water on tap in bathroom upstairs - downstairs & in basement - from soft water system & Crane water pressure system.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Coal, wood, kerosene, wood, heat.

Where did you get your fuel? Sometimes bought from someone, sometimes from the woods.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Fuel used now are much the same as when I started housekeeping except that for the past 25 years we have had electric light and power for washing & cleaning—also all water & fuel inside.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Things have been rather up to date when I first came west. If we were in Ontario where we bought hard, butter, syrup & molasses, etc., in bulk—taking our own jug for butter & having the former served to us on wooden "butter dishes" made in local mill—

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

In early years even after I came west folks wanted potatoes & meat for breakfast—but have changed over—perhaps about 15 or 20 yrs ago. Breakfast & "juice or fruit—Cereal—Toast & bacon or eggs—or both and in most cases—coffee."

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

In those days we didn't always have turkey—just chicken—I had no folks in this province so had my husband's father & mother—aged 63 & 53—his three brothers & three sisters aged 35-33, 27-26, 22 & 16 yrs. Also his brothers-in-law aged 32 & —one sister-in-law age 26—

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

In 1934-'34 we had complete crop failures and with five children to clothe & feed the situation was very grim—One evening all we had for supper was a stew made from a little bit of cabbage & carrot the hoppers had missed in the garden. Our potato crop was 3/4 less—so I told my husband we would have to apply for relief lest the little ones starve—He applied but had to wait a month for application to be accepted—in the mean time we scurried along but it was mighty hard to manage.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

We don't seem to eat as hearty now as in the old days and the preparation of meals is a lot simpler than they used to be.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

It is the other way round now for we are less dependent on purchased foods than ever before—it is true we buy our bread and butter while we ship our cream but we can still make bread and butter—can fruit & our own vegetables & meat as well as use a quick freeze locker in town.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

I'm afraid I'm a generation too late in giving you the details. Nearly pioneer days as the country was quite well established with railway-cars, stores etc when I came—It was my husband's people who settled here in 1909 who could give the details of hauling produce by supplies from Moose Jaw in all kinds of weather—If you wish—at a later date—I could obtain considerable local early history for you.

Mrs Wilson Knox.
